results.title: Bye Bye Bye
results.brief_description: In the year 2000, *Nsync waved bye, bye, bye to their second place status in the boy band race with the Backstreet Boys with this certified hit that’s music video memorably featured the troupe dancing on puppet strings.

constellations_other.name: Like a puppet on a string
constellations_other.description: From the silly to the sinister, puppets, muppets, dummies and toys on-screen.

results.title: Bye bye Birdie
results.creator_credit: Kohlmar-Sidney Productions, Columbia Pictures, Fred Kohlmar and George Sidney
results.brief_description: When a singer is drafted, a songwriter and his girlfriend decide to capitalize on the event. On national TV, Conrad Birdie will sing a song to a lucky teenager. Cast includes Janet Leigh, Dick Van Dyke, Ann-Margret, Maureen Stapleton, Bobby Rydell, Jesse Pearson and Ed Sullivan as himself. Based upon the play “Bye, bye, Birdie”, book by Michael Stewart with music and lyrics by Charles Strouse and Lee Adams.

results.title: By the seats of their pants
results.brief_description: When pilot Dick Scobee blasted off aboard the ill-fated Challenger space shuttle, he took with him a unique piece of Australia’s aviation history: a rib from Bert Hinkler’s glider. As Dick’s widow June recounts this same piece was miraculously recovered floating in the ocean amongst the Challenger debris. This programme is a fascinating look at Australia’s aviators. From pioneers such as Sir Charles Kingsford Smith, Charles Ulm and Lores Bonney, through to the pilots of both World Wars and Vietnam, to the barnstorming antics of today’s airmen and women. Experience the thrills of cattle mustering by helicopter in Australia’s wild outback, spectacular aerobatics in a rugged Pitt Special, the life-saving endeavours of the Royal Flying Doctor Service and low-level manoevres by cropduster adventurers. It is a first-hand account from the pilots who were and still are flying ‘by the seats of their pants’.

results.title: By the seat of our pants
results.creator_credit: Task Force, Social Welfare Dept of Victoria, Peter Norton, Julie Cutler and Peter Monger
results.brief_description: A film about the problems of unemployment. Interspersed with comments from sympathetic as well as unsympathetic ‘experts’, four young people living in Prahran tell their stories of largely unfortunate experiences with employers and government institutions.

results.title: By the light of the moon
results.creator_credit: Broadmeadows Secondary College, Christine Rogers, Alex Vagic and Media, Applied Communications, RMIT
results.brief_description: “By the light of the moon” tells the story of two refugee girls, their reasons for leaving their home countries, their experiences, and how they came to be living in Broadmeadows and attending the Broadmeadows Secondary College. Essentially the film is about hope and optimism. Despite the difficulties faced by the two girls, and an acknowledgement that they can never forget the past, through sharing their stories they gain acceptance. They begin to connect with the community in which they now live, and have hope for the future.

results.title: By nature's rules
results.creator_credit: Jim Lawless Motion Picture Consultants and Jim Lawless
results.brief_description: A doctor describes the condition of hypothermia, or exposure sickness, detailing its gradual effect on the mind and body. This slow numbing process of physical and mental faculties is then shown in a dramatic enactment of the experiences of a group of hikers who vary in stamina and in their knowledge of the dangers of inadequate protection against changes in weather. When one experienced climber recognizes the symptoms of hypothermia and takes positive action the symptoms and treatment of this insidious malady are clearly demonstrated.

results.title: By Lake and Stream
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Jack Keane
results.brief_description: An account of the work being done to maintain the trout population of Victorian lakes and streams. Shows the initial trapping of adult fish, stripping of eggs from the female fish, and subsequent hatching of young fry at the Snob’s Creek hatchery, keeping the young fish in brooding ponds, and finally the release of the trout to replenish lakes and streams. Various trout fishing techniques are demonstrated, and the film concludes with scenes of anglers in action in many parts of the State.

results.title: By hook or by crook
results.creator_credit: Christian Television Association of Victoria and Russell Sefton
results.brief_description: A film about early Christian Art examining the aesthetics and in particular, that of the catacombs of Rome. Pays special attention to the culltural-historical context from which it evolved. Presented by Barry Marshall.

results.title: By design?
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Diane O'Connor
results.brief_description: Provides a behind the scene look at the world of fashion. People from Cherry Lane fashion house, “Dolly” and “Mode” magazines and the Australian Wool corporation talk about what is involved in predicting fashions trends, designing, producing garments and putting together fashion.

results.title: By design
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Geoffrey Collings
results.brief_description: A jet plane, a boomerang, and a locomotive are shown as examples of successful design in which the right materials are used for the right purposes. Showing examples of the work of Australia’s industrial designers, the film explains that the purpose for which an article is intended determines the final design. Examples include household articles such as an electric iron, comfortable chairs, lamps, and saucepans.
